Housing and homelessness

Includes paying your rent, repairs, housing allocation, emergency and temporary accommodation and housing advice

  • Popular pages

    • Council and social housing We are a social housing landlord, providing advice and information to our tenants for council housing.
    • Homelessness and prevention Advice and guidance to help those facing homelessness

  • In this section

    • Private Sector Housing Includes information on housing standards, living conditions and making a complaint.
      • Housing standards – The Private Sector Housing team is here to ensure that the residents of Somerset live in homes that are safe, healthy and appropriate for their needs.
      • Complain about housing conditions – If you live in rented accommodation and are experiencing problems with the condition of your property, you may wish to make a complaint
      • Damp and Mould – Poor heating, insulation and ventilation can increase condensation, a common cause of damp and black mould in the home
      • House in Multiple Occupation Standards and Regulations – A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) is a property occupied by three or more people from more than one household
      • Houses in multiple occupation licensing – Licensing to make sure that the highest risk properties in the private rental market are identified, meet legal standards and are properly managed
      • Overcrowding – Find out about the government standard on overcrowding
      • Housing immigration – Sponsors for someone who is making an immigration application to come to the UK need to provide proof that the accommodation is of a suitable standard
    • Find a Home Includes affordable housing and other housing options
      • Homefinder Somerset – Homefinder Somerset is a choice-based lettings scheme for people to apply for social housing in Somerset.
      • Housing options for older people – There are lots of housing options available for older people depending on your circumstances.
      • Tenancy exchanges and mutual exchanges – A tenancy exchange is when you swap your home legally with another council or housing association tenant. It is often called a mutual exchange.
      • KeyRing Lettings – KeyRing Lettings offer a free, no obligation, rental appraisal and property advice session
      • Find a home to rent with a private landlord – How to find a home to rent with a private landlord, why this may be the best option for you, and how we can help
      • Affordable housing in Somerset – Information on affordable housing development and availability in Somerset
    • Somerset Independence Plus Home energy advice and assistance.

ai_business_case.letter:
To Our Esteemed CEO,

Subject: Usability Recommendations to Enhance Service Efficiency and Cost Savings on Council Housing Portal

Overview:
Our analysis of a representative customer persona, "David," a 52-year-old council tenant seeking minor flat modifications, highlights opportunities for improving the online service experience. David values clarity, minimal steps, and timely updates, which directly influence his satisfaction and trust in the council’s digital services.

Positive Feedback:
The current infrastructure appears to meet David's core needs—providing digital forms, photo uploads, and information about processes—which demonstrates a solid foundation. The feedback suggests that the online platform is sufficiently accessible for users with basic digital literacy. Excellent job, web team, on establishing these functionalities with user simplicity in mind.

Recommended Improvements & Impact:
However, to further enhance service efficiency, reduce operational costs, and increase customer satisfaction, I recommend the following targeted improvements:

1. Streamline Communication & Update Mechanisms:
   - Implement real-time status tracking for application submissions.
   - Enable push notifications or email alerts to keep David and similar users informed about decision progress and required actions.
   Impact: This reduces follow-up inquiries, decreases administrative workload, and assures tenants that their requests are prioritized, fostering trust and reducing anxiety.

2. Simplify the Online Form & Guidance:
   - Incorporate contextual help prompts and a clear checklist of acceptable modifications.
   - Use dynamic form fields that adapt based on user responses.
   Impact: This minimizes errors, prevents rejected applications, and reduces the need for follow-up clarifications, saving staff time and expediting decision turnaround times.

3. Responsive, Mobile-Friendly Design:
   - Ensure the application process and information pages are optimized for smartphones.
   Impact: Supports David’s preferred device, increasing completion rates and user engagement, especially among tenants comfortable with mobile devices.

4. Centralize and Clarify Policy & Guidance Info:
   - Provide a dedicated, easy-to-navigate FAQ and decision criteria section related to flat modifications.
   Impact: Empowers tenants with self-service capabilities, reducing inbound queries and staff workload.

5. Implement User Testing & Feedback Loops:
   - Regularly gather user feedback post-interaction via brief surveys or prompts.
   Impact: Continuous improvement based on real user experiences ensures iterative enhancements, aligning with customer needs.

Summary:
By integrating these improvements, the council could significantly elevate the user experience for tenants like David. This would not only ensure more efficient handling of applications but also deliver cost savings through reduced administrative overhead and decreased resource expenditure on follow-ups and correction processes.

I recommend prioritizing these enhancements to strengthen our digital service delivery, boost tenant satisfaction, and achieve measurable efficiency gains.

Respectfully,
[Your Name]
Web Usability & Service Optimization Lead
